title: R42621
content: Some in the 112th Congress wanted to cut international affairs spending, including foreign aid programs, to reduce the federal budget deficit. However, others believed a strong foreign affairs budget was crucial for national security and foreign policy interests, potentially saving money by avoiding costly military interventions. Congress considered the FY2013 Department of State appropriations in the context of the Budget Control Act of 2011. The House passed legislation (H.R. 933) on March 6, 2013, to fund federal programs for the remainder of FY2013. The Senate approved an expanded version on March 20, 2013, and it was signed into law on March 26, 2013 (P.L. 113-6). The State-Foreign Operations appropriation, representing about 1.5% of the total federal budget, supports international affairs programs and activities. The State-Foreign Operations appropriation, representing about 1.5% of the total federal budget, supports international affairs programs and activities, including foreign economic and security assistance, contributions to international organizations, State Department and USAID operations, public diplomacy, and international broadcasting programs. However, some international affairs programs like food aid and certain commissions are funded through other appropriations bills. The State-Foreign Operations appropriations bill funds international programs and activities, including foreign assistance and State Department operations. Some commissions like the International Boundary and Water Commission are also funded through this bill. Congressional activity related to this bill includes the FY2013 Defense and Military Construction/VA Continuing Resolution signed by President Obama on March 26, 2013. During the Cold War, foreign aid and diplomatic programs focused on anti-communism and other U.S. policy interests like economic development, trade promotion, education, health care, human rights, and environmental protection. Post-Cold War, new objectives emerged such as nuclear non-proliferation, drug trafficking prevention, peace efforts in the Middle East, regional stability, religious freedom, and combating human trafficking.
